posts.title: Building My Portfolio Website
posts.content:
Today I worked on adding a blog feature to my portfolio website. It's exciting to see how simple it can be to add dynamic content using just JSON and JavaScript.

The blog section will help me share my daily learnings and experiences with everyone who visits my site.

posts.title: Welcome to My Blog
posts.content: This is my first blog post! I'll be sharing my thoughts, experiences, and updates here regularly.

<!doctype html>

<html lang="en">

<head>

 <meta charset="utf-8" />

 <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1" />

 <title>Complete Beginner Guide: Set Up Two Servers With Vagrant and Install WordPress</title>

 <style>

  body{font-family:system-ui,-apple-system,Segoe UI,Roboto,"Helvetica Neue",Arial;line-height:1.6;color:#111;margin:0;padding:0;background:#f7f8fb}

  .container{max-width:920px;margin:28px auto;padding:28px;background:#fff;border-radius:8px;box-shadow:0 6px 24px rgba(20,20,40,.06)}

  h1{font-size:28px;margin:8px 0 12px}

  h2{font-size:20px;margin:20px 0 8px;color:#0b5cff}

  h3{font-size:16px;margin:16px 0 6px;color:#333}

  p{margin:8px 0}

  .note{background:#f1f8ff;border-left:4px solid #0b5cff;padding:10px 12px;border-radius:4px;margin:10px 0}

  .code{background:#0f1720;color:#dff2ff;padding:12px;border-radius:6px;overflow:auto;font-family:Menlo,Monaco,monospace;font-size:13px}

  pre{margin:0}

  .cmd{background:#0b1220;color:#dff2ff;padding:10px;border-radius:6px;overflow:auto;font-family:Menlo,Monaco,monospace;font-size:13px}

  ul{margin:8px 0 8px 20px}

  .check{color:green;font-weight:600}

  .warn{color:#c44141;font-weight:700}

  .meta{font-size:13px;color:#666;margin:6px 0}

  blockquote{margin:10px 0;padding:10px 12px;background:#fff7e6;border-left:4px solid #ffb300}

  .footer{font-size:13px;color:#666;margin-top:18px}

  a{color:#0b5cff}

 </style>

</head>

<body>

 <article class="container">

  <h1>Complete Beginner Guide: Set Up Two Servers With Vagrant and Install WordPress (Step-by-Step)</h1>

  <p class="meta">This guide is written for absolute beginners. Follow each step in order. After each step you will <strong>verify</strong> it worked. No prior Linux knowledge required.</p>


  <h2>What you will get</h2>

  <ul>

   <li>A <strong>web server</strong> (Apache + PHP + WordPress) at <code>192.168.56.2</code></li>

   <li>A <strong>database server</strong> (MySQL) at <code>192.168.56.3</code></li>

   <li>Full Vagrant setup using the Bento Ubuntu 24.04 box (<code>bento/ubuntu-24.04</code>)</li>

   <li>Ping tests to confirm connectivity and step-by-step verification</li>

  </ul>


  <h2>Before you start (Host machine)</h2>

  <p>Do these on your actual computer (not inside Vagrant). We will install VirtualBox and Vagrant.</p>


  <h3>1. Install VirtualBox</h3>

  <ol>

   <li>Go to <a href="https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads</a></li>

   <li>Download the installer for your OS (Windows/Mac/Linux) and run it (Next → Next → Install).</li>

  </ol>

  <div class="note">

   <strong>Verification (Windows):</strong> Press <strong>Windows Key</strong>, type <code>cmd</code>, press Enter. In the terminal run:

   <div class="cmd"><pre>VBoxManage --version</pre></div>

   You should see a version number like <code>7.0.x</code>. If you see an error, reinstall VirtualBox.

  </div>


  <h3>2. Install Vagrant</h3>

  <ol>

   <li>Go to <a href="https://developer.hashicorp.com/vagrant/downloads" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://developer.hashicorp.com/vagrant/downloads</a></li>

   <li>Download the installer for your OS and run it.</li>

  </ol>

  <div class="note">

   <strong>Verification:</strong> Open a terminal/command prompt and run:

   <div class="cmd"><pre>vagrant --version</pre></div>

   You should see something like <code>Vagrant 2.4.x</code>.

  </div>


  <h2>Create project folder and Vagrantfile</h2>

  <p>Make a new folder for the project. Example: <code>Desktop/wordpress-lab</code></p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>mkdir ~/Desktop/wordpress-lab

cd ~/Desktop/wordpress-lab</pre></div>


  <h3>Create the Vagrantfile</h3>

  <p>Inside your project folder create a file named <code>Vagrantfile</code> and paste the exact code below. This uses the Bento Ubuntu 24.04 box and the box version you asked for:</p>


  <div class="code"><pre>

Vagrant.configure("2") do |config|

 config.vm.box = "bento/ubuntu-24.04"

 config.vm.box_version = "202510.26.0"


 # ---------------- WEB SERVER ----------------

 config.vm.define "web" do |web|

  web.vm.provider "virtualbox" do |vb|

   vb.memory = "1024"

   vb.cpus = 2

  end


  # Correct place for network config

  web.vm.network "private_network", ip: "192.168.56.2"


  web.vm.provision "shell", inline: <<-SHELL

   apt update -y

   apt install apache2 -y

   systemctl start apache2

  SHELL

 end


 # ---------------- DATABASE SERVER ----------------

 config.vm.define "db" do |db|

  db.vm.provider "virtualbox" do |vb|

   vb.memory = "512"

   vb.cpus = 1

  end


  # Correct place for network config

  db.vm.network "private_network", ip: "192.168.56.3"


  db.vm.provision "shell", inline: <<-SHELL

   apt-get update -y

   apt install mysql-server -y

   systemctl enable mysql

   systemctl start mysql

   echo "Database server setup completed"

  SHELL

 end

end

  </pre></div>


  <div class="note"><strong>Why this box?</strong> The Bento Ubuntu 24.04 box is a stable, widely used image for Vagrant labs. The Vagrantfile uses <code>config.vm.box = "bento/ubuntu-24.04"</code> and <code>config.vm.box_version = "202510.26.0"</code> exactly as you requested.</div>


  <h2>Boot the virtual machines</h2>

  <p>Run this inside the <code>wordpress-lab</code> folder on your host:</p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>vagrant validate    # checks the Vagrantfile

vagrant up        # creates the two machines and provisions them</pre></div>


  <div class="note">

   <strong>Verification:</strong> After <code>vagrant up</code> finishes run:

   <div class="cmd"><pre>vagrant status</pre></div>

   You should see both machines as <span class="check">running</span>:

   <pre>web  running

db   running</pre>

  </div>


  <h2>Step-by-step inside each VM (what to run and how to check)</h2>


  <h3>WEB server (machine name: <code>web</code>, IP: <code>192.168.56.2</code>)</h3>


  <h4>Open a terminal on your host and connect to web:</h4>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>vagrant ssh web</pre></div>


  <h4>Verify you are inside the web VM:</h4>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>whoami

# expected output: vagrant</pre></div>


  <h4>Check Apache status (web VM):</h4>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>sudo systemctl status apache2 --no-pager</pre></div>

  <p><strong>Expected:</strong> you should see <code>active (running)</code>. If not, start Apache:</p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>sudo systemctl start apache2</pre></div>


  <h4>Browser check (host machine):</h4>

  <p>Open your web browser and go to <strong>http://192.168.56.2</strong>. You should see the Apache default page. If you see it — web server is working.</p>


  <h3>DB server (machine name: <code>db</code>, IP: <code>192.168.56.3</code>)</h3>


  <h4>Connect from your host to db:</h4>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>vagrant ssh db</pre></div>


  <h4>Check MySQL is installed and running (db VM):</h4>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>mysql --version

sudo systemctl status mysql --no-pager</pre></div>

  <p><strong>Expected:</strong> <code>mysql --version</code> shows a version and <code>systemctl</code> shows <code>active (running)</code>.</p>


  <h2>Network connectivity tests (ping) — important!</h2>

  <p>We must verify both VMs can talk to each other (this ensures WordPress can reach MySQL).</p>


  <h4>From <strong>web</strong> → <strong>db</strong> (web VM):</h4>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>ping -c 4 192.168.56.3</pre></div>

  <p><strong>Expected:</strong> replies with <code>0% packet loss</code>. If you get packet loss or timeouts, stop and review the Vagrantfile and network settings.</p>


  <h4>From <strong>db</strong> → <strong>web</strong> (db VM):</h4>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>vagrant ssh db

ping -c 4 192.168.56.2</pre></div>

  <p><strong>Expected:</strong> replies with <code>0% packet loss</code>.</p>


  <h2>Install WordPress dependencies (do this on the <strong>web</strong> VM)</h2>

  <p>In the web VM run these commands to install PHP and other packages WordPress needs (we include <code>mysql-client</code> so PHP can talk to MySQL):</p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>sudo apt update

sudo apt install -y apache2 ghostscript libapache2-mod-php mysql-client \

php php-bcmath php-curl php-imagick php-intl php-json php-mbstring \

php-mysql php-xml php-zip unzip</pre></div>


  <p><strong>Verification:</strong></p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>php -v    # shows PHP version

apache2 -v  # shows Apache version</pre></div>


  <h2>Download WordPress and set directory (web VM)</h2>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>sudo mkdir -p /srv/www

sudo chown www-data: /srv/www

curl https://wordpress.org/latest.tar.gz | sudo -u www-data tar zx -C /srv/www</pre></div>


  <p><strong>Verification:</strong></p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>ls -la /srv/www/wordpress

# expected: wp-admin wp-content wp-includes index.php wp-config-sample.php</pre></div>


  <h2>Configure Apache VirtualHost for WordPress (web VM)</h2>

  <p>Create an Apache site file and enable it:</p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>sudo tee /etc/apache2/sites-available/wordpress.conf > /dev/null <<EOF

<VirtualHost *:80>

  DocumentRoot /srv/www/wordpress

  <Directory /srv/www/wordpress>

    AllowOverride All

    Require all granted

  </Directory>

</VirtualHost>

EOF


sudo a2ensite wordpress

sudo a2enmod rewrite

sudo a2dissite 000-default

sudo systemctl reload apache2</pre></div>


  <p><strong>Verification:</strong> Open <code>http://192.168.56.2</code> in your browser — you should now be at the WordPress installation page (it may show a setup wizard or a message that database is required).</p>


  <h2>Create database and user (do this on the <strong>db</strong> VM)</h2>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>vagrant ssh db

sudo mysql -u root</pre></div>


  <p>Inside the MySQL prompt run:</p>

  <div class="code"><pre>CREATE DATABASE wordpress;

CREATE USER 'wpuser'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY 'Password123';

GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON wordpress.* TO 'wpuser'@'%';

FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

EXIT;</pre></div>


  <p><strong>Verification (db VM shell):</strong></p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>sudo mysql -e "SHOW DATABASES;" | grep wordpress

# should print "wordpress"</pre></div>


  <h2>Allow MySQL to accept remote connections (db VM)</h2>

  <p>Edit the bind address and restart MySQL (this allows the web VM to connect to MySQL):</p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>sudo sed -i "s/^bind-address.*/bind-address = 0.0.0.0/" /etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf

sudo systemctl restart mysql</pre></div>


  <p><strong>Verification:</strong> Check MySQL is listening:</p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>sudo ss -tulpn | grep mysql

# you should see 0.0.0.0:3306 (or similar)</pre></div>


  <h2>Configure WordPress to use the remote DB (web VM)</h2>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>sudo -u www-data cp /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config-sample.php /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php


# Replace database placeholders

sudo -u www-data sed -i "s/database_name_here/wordpress/" /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php

sudo -u www-data sed -i "s/username_here/wpuser/" /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php

sudo -u www-data sed -i "s/password_here/Password123/" /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php

sudo -u www-data sed -i "s/localhost/192.168.56.3/" /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php


# Add secure salts (recommended)

curl https://api.wordpress.org/secret-key/1.1/salt/ | sudo -u www-data tee -a /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php</pre></div>


  <p><strong>Verification:</strong></p>

  <div class="cmd"><pre>grep -n "DB_HOST" /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php

# should show DB_HOST line with 192.168.56.3</pre></div>


  <h2>Finish WordPress setup in your browser (host machine)</h2>

  <p>Open <strong>http://192.168.56.2</strong>. You should see the WordPress install wizard. Fill the form:</p>

  <ul>

   <li>Site Title: <em>My DevOps Site</em></li>

   <li>Admin Username: <em>admin</em> (or any you choose)</li>

   <li>Admin Password: choose a strong password</li>

   <li>Email: your email</li>

  </ul>


  <p>Click <strong>Install WordPress</strong> and then log in at <code>http://192.168.56.2/wp-admin</code>.</p>


  <h2>Write your first blog post — <em>Linux for DevOps</em></h2>

  <ol>

   <li>In WP Admin go to <strong>Posts → Add New</strong></li>

   <li>Title: <strong>Linux for DevOps</strong></li>

   <li>Write your content and click <strong>Publish</strong></li>

  </ol>

  <p><strong>Verification:</strong> Open <code>http://192.168.56.2</code> and confirm your post is visible.</p>


  <h2>Troubleshooting checklist (quick)</h2>

  <ul>

   <li><code>vagrant status</code> — both VMs must be <span class="check">running</span></li>

   <li>From web VM: <code>systemctl status apache2</code> — should be <span class="check">active (running)</span></li>

   <li>From db VM: <code>systemctl status mysql</code> — should be <span class="check">active (running)</span></li>

   <li>Ping tests — <code>ping -c4 192.168.56.3</code> (from web) and <code>ping -c4 192.168.56.2</code> (from db) should have <span class="check">0% packet loss</span></li>

   <li>If WordPress shows DB connection error — re-check <code>/srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php</code>, MySQL bind address, and DB user privileges.</li>

  </ul>


  <blockquote>Security reminder: for learning and labs this configuration is fine. For production systems never bind MySQL to 0.0.0.0 without firewall rules and use strong passwords and restricted user hosts.</blockquote>


  <div class="footer">

   <p>If you want, I can convert this into a clean HTML file with images/screenshots for each verification step or provide a downloadable zip with the Vagrantfile and a README. Reply with <strong>“screenshots”</strong> or <strong>“zip”</strong> and I’ll prepare it.</p>

   <p>Good luck — paste this into your WordPress HTML block and follow the steps exactly. If anything fails, copy the exact error message and paste it back here and I will help troubleshoot.</p>

  </div>

 </article>

</body>

</html>
